steps: If they can cough effectively, encourage them to keep coughing.
If they cannot breathe, cough, or speak, give 5 back blows between the shoulder blades.
If back blows fail, give 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
Alternate between 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until the object is expelled.

steps: Call emergency services immediately for severe bleeding.
Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or sterile dressing.
Maintain pressure until the bleeding stops. Do not remove the cloth if it soaks through; add more layers on top.
If the wound is on a limb and bleeding is life-threatening, a tourniquet may be considered if trained to do so.
Keep the person lying down and warm to prevent shock.
red_flags: Signs of shock (pale, cold, clammy skin)

steps: Check for a response (shake shoulders and ask 'Are you okay?').
If unresponsive, check for breathing for no more than 10 seconds.
If not breathing or only gasping, call emergency services immediately.
Start CPR: 30 chest compressions (push hard and fast in center of chest).
Give 2 rescue breaths if trained, otherwise continue with continuous chest compressions.
Use an AED (defibrillator) as soon as one is available.
